title: Rams rout reeling Falcons in Jalen Ramsey's first game after trade
text:
CLOSE Check out some early NFL headlines. USA TODAY

ATLANTA — The easy narrative Sunday when two of the NFL’s most disappointing teams met at Mercedes-Benz Stadium was that one of them would emerge with a chance to turn around their season, while the other would reach the point of no return.

But it's now clear that this was a mischaracterization. Whatever problems the Los Angeles Rams have had the last few weeks are nothing compared to the utter chaos and dysfunction that has ensnared the Atlanta Falcons.

When it comes to a season swirling the drain, the Falcons proved the Rams aren't even in their league as L.A. coasted to a 37-10 win. Atlanta, a team many experts predicted to contend for the NFC title, has fallen to a stunning 1-6 while the Rams stopped a three-game losing streak and improved to 4-3. Here are three things we learned from this one:

1. Dan Quinn's job is really in jeopardy

Though it’s unclear what owner Arthur Blank’s intentions are, the Falcons’ coach shouldn’t feel too confident he’ll have a job much longer. This team is a mess on both sides of the ball, but the defense is Quinn’s baby. Atlanta was 27th in the NFL coming into this game in total defense and 31st in points allowed at 31 per game. Nothing we saw against the Rams showed any sign of improvement, as the Rams finished with 381 yards of offense. Another key stat that speaks directly to preparation: Atlanta has a minus-70 point differential in first halves this season, the worst mark in the league.

Atlanta plays the Seattle Seahawks at home next Sunday, and many have pointed to the subsequent bye week as a sensible time to execute a coaching change. But after getting embarrassed at home yet again in front of tens of thousands of empty seats, what's the point in waiting?

2. The Rams’ offense showed signs of life

Coming off their Super Bowl loss last season, the Rams have a huge target on their back. So does coach Sean McVay, in a sense, as teams have now had a couple years to look closely at his offense and make adjustments. When the San Francisco 49ers held the Rams to 157 yards of offense last week, some critics were asking if McVay has been “figured out.”

If nothing else, playing the Falcons gave the Rams a confidence boost as they only punted once in each half and slammed the door on this game with a strong nine-play, 75-yard touchdown drive to take a 20-3 lead coming out of halftime.

Quarterback Jared Goff missed a few throws, but he didn’t make any big mistakes, either, completing 22 of 37 passes for 268 yards and a pair of touchdowns. He also executed a pretty impressive juke on Falcons linebacker Deion Jones as he waltzed in for a 1-yard touchdown run in the third quarter.

L.A. also did a nice job of getting rookie running back Darrell Henderson more involved. Henderson, a third-round draft pick out of Memphis, supplemented Todd Gurley’s 18 carries with 11 of his own for 31 yards and caught a pass out of the backfield.

3. Jalen Ramsey was a difference-maker

Ramsey, the two-time Pro Bowl defensive back, made his debut Sunday after getting traded from Jacksonville and was essentially glued to Falcons star receiver Julio Jones throughout the game.

Though Jones caught six passes for 93 yards, including beating Ramsey on one deep ball late in the first half for a 39-yard gain, Ramsey was largely effective in making sure he didn’t get open. His ability to play Jones one-on-one also allowed the Rams to focus on the Falcons’ other weapons, and they really struggled to move the ball for most of the game.

Atlanta only had 224 yards, 75 of which came on a late touchdown drive led by backup quarterback Matt Schaub, who came in after Matt Ryan suffered an unspecified ankle injury.

Follow Dan Wolken on Twitter @DanWolken.
description: The Rams broke a three-game slide by coming on strong against a Falcons team that can't seem to find its footing this season.
